name: Bicycle Quarterly's Calendar of Classic Bicycles 2014
description: Bicycle Quarterly's Calendar of Classic Bicycles 2014 For 2014, Bicycle Quarterly present a calendar with studio photos of 13 classic bicycles. The magnificent 1951 René Herse Randonneuse on the cover leads into an eclectic mix of racing and cyclotouring bikes. Fans of racing bikes will enjoy Greg LeMond’s Gitane, Guiseppe Saronni’s Colnago, and a 1930s Caminargent with aluminum frame. Cyclotouring bikes include machines from Alex Singer, René Herse and Jo Routens, as well as the incredible Faure; made by a French jeweler. Counterpoints are provided by a Hirondelle Retro-Directe, a Labor with its single-leg fork, and a tandem that set the hour record in the 1930s. In addition to some photos that have been featured in books from Bicycle Quarterly Press, the calendar shows many previously unpublished detail photographs. Free UK delivery Tweet

name: Simpson Magazine Issue 3
description: Simpson Magazine Issue 3 Simpson is an entirely independent publication, that aims to convey the true essence of what it’s like to ride a road bike. Another Grand Tour, another great Simpson spectating adventure. They travelled to Spain to witness a stage of the Vuelta a España and had an interesting time negotiating the roads and the rules and a rather spooky hotel. They also tried out three different ways of watching the 100th edition of the Tour de France without crossing the channel. They followed the fortunes of one lucky reader as he had his dream bike built by up-and-coming London frame-builder Jake Rusby. They also report on the inaugural ride of Simpson CC and, bearing in mind the rough ride Wiggo’s been getting lately, they ask why the Brits are so quick to turn on their sporting heroes. Contents Include: Kit you can’t do without Simpson favourite The fallibility of British Champions Why I love this bike Le Tour 100 celebrated Building your dream bike Vuelta a España 2013 On ride nutrition London to Brighton club ride Riders stories Guitars and cycling Pedal quiz Sharing the knowledge Food for thought: energy bars Dos and Dont's: Strava Size: 92 pages 235 x 174mm Fully independent and advert free Tweet

name: The Boneshaker Almanac Volume 9
description: The Boneshaker Almanac Volume 9 (BA43-400) Modeled loosely after the United States War Department’s 1941 Soldier’s Basic Field Manual, Boneshaker: A Bicycling Almanac fashions itself to be the practical bicyclist’s literary periodical-style handbook. Their travels have taken them off the beaten path this summer, but they’re home once more and have for you, finally and irrevocably, the latest issue of Boneshaker: A Bicycling Almanac. Not unlike Autumn itself, this issue has a little bit of everything, from love letters and boys’ songs, to reminiscent curses and musings. Within these pages you’ll find poetry by Georgia’s J.P. Wares and Oregon’s Susan Denning and Genevieve Hudson, along with artwork by the talented Heather Dunn and the ever-raucous Mike Compton. Maureen Foley’s adventures of Smidge and Space roll toward an enlightening conclusion. Two friends climb a steep ascent and search secrets about themselves in Robert Grunau’s touching story. But wait, there’s more! Mel Wells wonders why she’s on a bike in Belgium taking the gospel door to door. Valerie Steen bike commutes in Alaska—where it’s fifty below zero. Brett Albert Poulin demonstrates how to make a DIY frame bag. Their French correspondent Florent Carriere covers an alleycat race in Lyon. PhD candidate Jared McBride thinks deeply on why and how we transport ourselves. Katie Boehnlien rides through four amazing seasons. And to top the issue off, Bike Commuter Betty offers advice on dealing with scofflaws, and Stan Engelbrecht and Nic Grobler give you a photographic interview of bike commuters in South Africa. In all, this issue is a testament to the fact that a cyclist is shaped and constantly remade by the sheer physicality and exhilaration of the bike ride itself. Bicycling, as you well know, profoundly affects the way one sees the world. 128 pages, perfect bound Free UK delivery Tweet

name: Boneshaker Magazine Issue 12
description: Boneshaker Magazine Issue 12 From its butterfly-fluttering cover to its freewheeling final page, Boneshaker #12 explores forgotten railroads, tours with travelling minstrels and jumps into freezing lakes. From rickshaw politics to open-source cargo bikes, from racing with missing limbs to riding in search of the simple life - there's poetry, strangeness and inspiration in equal measure. As ever, they've woven in the work of some wonderful illustrators, photographers and writers from around the world to bring all these bicycle stories to life. name: The Ride Journal Issue 7
description: The Ride Journal Issue 7 With so many readers happy with their secret formula issue seven is a case of “if it ain’t broke then don’t fix it.” Combining the usual selection of personal tales, original illustration and amazing photography they have (hopefully) created the ideal antidote to the winter blues. Any type of bike, any location and any story: Inspiring people either to get out and ride, or to get a cup of tea and escape into other cyclists lives. They leap across the globe with tales from Laos, Nevis, New Zealand and Bhutan (amongst others). They follow the full path from children learning, people commuting, weekend racing all the way up to competing in the Olympics and winning the Tour de France. If you have even the smallest interest in anything cycling then you should be able to find something to enjoy in Issue 7 of The Ride Journal. This is a weighty magazine, price includes UK postage Tweet

name: Bicycle (Leporello) by Ugo Gattoni
description: Bicycle (Leporello) by Ugo Gattoni A Leporello is a folded single sheet, folded zig-zag fashion, often referred to as accordion pleat. Inspired by the 2012 London Olympic Games, Ugo Gattoni intricately drew a gigantic cycle race through the streets of England's capital. Gattoni depicts the street race to end all street races with an astonishingly detailed illustration that totals over twelve feet in length. As the reader's eyes travel alongside "Bicycle"'s speeding cyclists, it soon becomes clear that this is no ordinary contest. Joining the elite athletes is a whole bunch of people including cycle couriers, commuters, bankers, delivery boys, mums with kids, youths on stolen mountain bikes, fashionistas, and hipsters riding their fixed gear bikes. Featuring an embossed wrap-around jacket, Bicycle has been expertly manufactured in the European Union to the highest standards. Beautifully printed, this specially designed, extra-large concertina title can be read as a book or displayed as an Olympic-sized work of art. In a brilliant alternative take on the biggest sporting event of 2012, Gattoni combines homage with humor in this two-wheeled free-for-all. Bicycle unfolds to nearly 2 metres in length, with intricate drawings on both sides, it forms, overall, a continuous scene of almost 4 metres. Price includes UK delivery Tweet

name: Fixation DVD (A Fixed Gear Documentary) SOLD OUT
description: Fixation: A Fixed Gear Documentary A Film by Alex Trudeau Viriato Winner of Best Short Documentary of 2011, San Francisco Frozen Film Festival Official Selection and Honarable Mention Best Documentary, DocUtah International Film Festival Fixation is a real documentary, focusing on the world of fixed gear cycling. This film captures the excitement and popularity of this growing sport from all perspectives. With the resurgence of this original form of cycling, they discover the appeal to having only one gear. Though technology has developed multiple speed bicycles, for faster and easier riding, both fixed and freewheel single speeds continue to have a strong following. The range of riders is vast, from professionals to the casual everyday rider. Their styles and motives are different, but their outcome seems to be the same: the freedom, the simplicity and the challenge of having one gear is what brings them back to the basics. The film explores the full spectrum of riding fixed: Messengers, Olympic Racing, City Riders, Bike Polo, Brakeless, Freestyle and more. Fixation showcases the different personalities of those involved with fixed gear cycling community, in San Francisco, Los Angeles and San Jose. The film also features interviews with Sean Martin, a prominent member of the LA cycling community; racing champions Marc Marino and John Christopher Gabriel, Bradley Woehl, owner of American Cyclery in San Francisco, Mark Cosio, owner of iMiNUSD in San Jose; and Jamie Staff, Olympian and the director of sprint racing for USA Cycling. Running time: 40 minutes Extras: Bonus Clips: City Grounds, Long Beach, CA and Jances and Jon Cycling Los Angeles Day/Night PLEASE NOTE: It looks like these are region 1 DVDs, please ensure your system can play them! Tweet

name: Line of Sight DVD/Book Digipak
description: Line of Sight DVD/Book Digipak Line of Sight is the inside story of underground bicycle racing around the word. More than just a montage of vehicle-dodging, fast paced action, Line of Sight also gives the viewers an insight into the community of bicycle messengers who run and participate in these underground races. Film Maker Lucas Brunelle is an an internationally renowned cycling videographer, infamous for his daredevil riding style. Brunelle's films on urban cycling have become, to many, the image of alleycat racing. Line of Sight features 10 year's worth of footage, edited down to a 60 minute film, showcasing the bicycle messenger culture and lifestyle throughout the world. Donning a customized helmet cam, Brunelle has followed some of the world's fastest bike messengers to bring us this inside story of underground bike racing. We get a glimpse of what urban cycling looks like in some of the world's most chaotic city streets and locales, the film features footage from the US, Mexico, Greece, Japan, Guatemala and the UK, it even makes a stop at the Great Wall of China. The main feature is 60 minutes in duration with titles by Futura 2000, plus extras and outtakes the digipak also includes a 40 page art book featuring photography and spoke cards from a decade of alleycat races around the world. Free UK delivery Tweet

name: The Boneshaker Almanac Volume 8
description: The Boneshaker Almanac Volume 8 (BA43-300) Modeled loosely after the United States War Department’s 1941 Soldier’s Basic Field Manual, Boneshaker: A Bicycling Almanac fashions itself to be the practical bicyclist’s literary periodical-style handbook. Autumn is upon us, and it’s the perfect time to sink your teeth into the latest issue of Boneshaker, which they have loaded with great stories and news from the bicycle home front. Think of it like gourmet trail mix-you know, the kind with bits of crystallized ginger and chocolate chips. There’s plenty of fuel here to keep you going when the road gets long and the going tough. Enjoy Marc-Andre Chimonas’ handy guide to manufacturing your own chain-keeper. Flip ahead to more from graphic novelist Maureen Foley, and the continuing adventures of Smidge and Space. Brush up on your bike shop etiquette with a cheat-sheet from Jacob English, owner of Mountain Road Cycles in Ohio. In their latest issue, you’ll find dreams and their interpretations, Dutch cookies, a kangaroo, and a celebration of the new moon. Because it can be dangerous out there on the open road, they bring you bike safety statistics, poems on healing after a hurt, and messages to send to your fellow riders. Because the best medicine is found somewhere between laughter and tears, they’re including a hilarious found poem courtesy of Craigslist, and an excerpt from Johnathon Allen’s non-fiction novel Doppelganger Effect. Top it off with a profile of Yendra’s tricycle built for beer, and you’ve got your Winter reading cut out for you. Cheers, and here’s to you, bicycle army! Boneshaker Almanac volume 8 comes with a free postcard by cover artist Jeff Nye 128 pages, perfect bound Free UK delivery Tweet

That's 300 pages of Boneshaker loveliness for the absolutely bargain price of just £20 including postage within the UK (+ postage for overseas). Boneshaker Magazine is a perfect-bound, ad-free quarterly publication celebrating bicycles and the people who ride them. From all around the world, they gather stories exploring the wonderful things that happen when people and bikes come together. They're about freedom, friendship and adventure - the human side of cycling. Whilst they love a beautiful bicycle as much as anyone, Boneshaker’s more about what bicycles can do than what they look like. No training tips, race diets or adverts. It's not how much your bike weighs that matters, but where it takes you. It's not how fast you got there, but what you saw on the way. Boneshaker is fully independent and advert free. Tweet

name: Boneshaker Magazine Issue 10
description: Cycling and theatre don’t often get mentioned in the same sentence - but there’s a shared grace, balance and physical dedication inherent in both. The piece 'Breakaway Stages' takes in Don Quixote by Bike, Godiva Awakes from the cutural Olympiad and other theatre groups using bicycles to explore the world around them as their stage. David Serrano's photo story turns the camera on the spectators of a touring stage and shows the theatre thats behind these big events.We hear from bee-keeping bikers, catch up with two very different bike projects in Toulon and New York and feature an amusing ode to something very familiar to everyday cyclist - the 'potbelly'. Also, Boneshaker’s reached issue 10 - they’ve come a long way since the wide-eyed first forays of issue 1. To have reached their tenth issue with all there positivity and pure-heartedness intact really does feel like a significant point; and a bit like a birthday. So slip a couple of beers into your pannier alongside issue 10, roll out to your favourite spot and join in celebrating. name: Yanco & Tracko Ramblin' Roll (Tool Roll) SOLD OUT
description: Yanco & Tracko Ramblin' Roll Tool Roll A collaborative project by Yancopads and Trackosaurus Rex Made from Black Cordura with Black trim, with 3 pouches for your tool kit essentials (multi tool, spare tube, tyre levers etc). When opened these measure 26cm by 24cm, and if you're not taking a bag they can be folded down really small and hung on the saddle rails (see the last photo). Handmade in the United States by Yanco. This from Tracko: Let's talk packing. The tube always goes in the middle pocket and depending on how big it is it may need to be in a plastic bag to slide in easily. The Ramblin' Roll works with all road tubes and most cyclocross tubes. The CO2 cartridge, valve and small multi-tool in the left pocket. The far right is reserved for emergency money, rolling papers and tyre lever. Fold flap down, fold right and fold left side in. Like any tool roll, the Ramblin' Roll works best with it is compressed as tight as possible. I also like to keep all edges lined up, giving the Ramblin Roll a very tight and compact look. We likes things tight and tidy around here. When installing the Ramblin' Roll to the bike you wanna position the webbing on top, tuck in between your saddle's rails and place webbing over both rail, then wrap it around the Ramblin' Roll, insert into binding buckle, tighten down and tuck webbing into webbing-loop. name: Just Ride
description: Just Ride: A Radically Practical Guide to Bikes, Equipment, Health, Safety, and Attitude by Grant Petersen founder of Rivendell Bicycle Works A collection of eighty-nine micro-essays on many familiar and some unfamiliar topics. The chapters are: Riding, Dressing, Safety, Health & Fitness, Accessories, Upkeep, Technicalities, and Velosophy. There’s a mix of instruction and opinion, and as a Free Bonus, you get medical advice involving the drawing of blood. All in all, Just Ride is sort of a manual for the Unracer—the rider looking for a reason to shuck the click-in pedals and uncomfortable bikes and grueling rides, without feeling like it’s throwing in the towel. It’s full of suggestions and recommendation on riding your bike outside the strange and often dysfunctional influences of racing, and having a better time on the bike because of it. 212 pages Free UK delivery Tweet

name: Rad Rides: The Best BMX Bikes of All Time
description: Rad Rides: The Best BMX Bikes of All Time by Intercity, Gavin Lucas & Stuart Robinson Rad Rides is the most in-depth exploration of the world of BMX bikes through their riders and the culture that surrounds them. The introduction explains and contextualizes the birth of BMX culture and where it is now, while the main body features bikes ranging from those that are well-worn through years of riding to beautiful, sculptural works of art – gleaming, built-but-never-ridden keepsakes. The featured bikes are organized decade by decade and are BMXs drawn from the best collections in the world. There are also in-depth details of specifications and interviews with some of the collectors, many of whom have had their bikes exclusively shot for the book. This is the indispensable companion for anyone who loves the BMX. Contents: Introduction, 1970s The birth of BMX, 1980s, 1990s, 2000–present. In addition to the four main sections there are also the following features on BMX culture - BMX collectors, The multiple disciplines of BMX, Ephemera and a Contributors’ glossary. name: Bike Snob: The Enlightened Cyclist
description: The Enlightened Cyclist: Commuter Angst, Dangerous Drivers, and Other Obstacles on the Path to Two-Wheeled Transcendence by Eben Weiss The joys of commuting by bike attract scores of new converts every year. But as fresh-faced cyclists fill the roads, they also encounter their share of frustrations—careless drivers, wide-flung car doors, zoned-out pedestrians, and aggressive fellow cyclists, to name a few. In this follow-up to the best-selling Bike Snob, BikeSnobNYC takes on the trials and triumphs of bike commuting with snark, humor, and enthusiasm, asking the question: If we become better commuters, will that make us better people? From the deadly sins of biking to tactics for dealing with cars, pedestrians, and other cyclists, this primer on bike travel is a must-read for cyclists new and seasoned alike. Hardcover, 5 x 7 in, 224 pages, 15 x 2-color images Free UK Shipping Tweet

name: Cycle Style Book SOLD OUT
description: Cycle Style by Horst A. Friedrichs No city boasts of a more fashionable population of bicyclists than London. Photographer Horst Friedrichs meets his subjects in their own milieu: zooming around the city's streets on two wheels. There he encounters a dazzling array of style and a surprising amount of substance. In tweeds (both Harris and hipster) and Saville Row suits, in high-tops and stilettos, in flowing skirts and the skinniest jeans, wildly tattooed and impeccably manicured, sporting bowler hats and racing caps, London's cyclists are jubilantly exercising their fashion freedom. Whether they're leisurely filling their baskets from market to home or pedalling purposefully to an important meeting, experiencing the city as cycling tourists, or getting from place to place in the most economical way possible, Friedrichs' subjects share a love of the bicycle culture that is sweeping the streets of London and the rest of the world. Card cover, 196 full colour pages Free UK delivery Tweet

name: Empire DVD & Limited Poster Bundle
description: Empire A film by Luke Stiles & Christian Thormann Empire is a movie about having fun riding your bike New York City. In the tradition of BMX and skate movies, Empire follows New York’s best fixed gear riders and a few special out-of-town guests in and out of traffic all over New York City. Inspired by MASH and Lucas Brunelle, Empire is the first full-length fixed gear film shot entirely in New York City. Featured riders include Tom Lamarche, WONKA, Dwaine, Yatika Starr Fields, Dagga, John Prolly, Kai Perez and surprise guests. The DVD contains the nearly hour long feature, which screened to sold out audiences around the world for Bicycle Film Festival. It also includes a friends section with many surprises, all the internet trailers and over an hour of never-before-seen footage. This beautiful package was designed by Jonah Birns, the man behind the look of the Red Hook Crit. The cover features Empire rider Dwain, and the interior is a stunning shot of a working messenger down Sixth Avenue taken by Christian Thormann. The poster is the main image from the DVD cover featuring Empire rider Dwain. This stunning photograph, taken by Christian Thormann, was transformed into the Empire DVD cover by Jonah Birns as a beautiful photo-illustration evoking a classic Marvel comic book cover. The poster is 43cm x 28cm (approx A3 size) and will be sent flat in a carded envelope. Free UK Delivery Tweet

description: Yehuda Moon and the Kickstand Cyclery Vol 1 Life on a Bicycle Read the on-road and retail adventures of Yehuda Moon! This is the first album of collected comic strips and contains strips from January 22, 2008 through December 31, 2008. You'll meet a bevy of characters whom Yehuda and Joe encounter: the bike ninja, the bike hypochondriac, their elderly compatriot Fred, the Shakers who build the bicycle frames, neighborhood kids starting riding clubs, roadies, commuters, and many more. Extra features include comic design notes and early character sketches. 8" x 10" full colour book with cardstock perfect binding. 96 full color pages of strips from 2008 (approx 340 strips) Signed by Rick Smith Price includes UK delivery Tweet

name: A Simple Machine, Like the Lever
description: A Simple Machine, Like the Lever A Novel by the Boneshaker Almanac editor Evan P. Schneider Nicholas Allander, 31—carless and careerless—is trying to get his life on track while holding his head high. He’s trying to pay off his debt, impress his girlfriend, keep his job, cast off his introversion, and accept the world’s imperfections without abandoning his heart. Unsure of what moves to make, though, he considers growing his beard, taking up alcoholism, abandoning scrounging, and owning an automobile—before too much slips by. All the while he clings to his bicycle, a simple machine whose purpose and workings he grasps. Nick’s struggle to position his aesthetic within the world is the story of a perfectionist who is far from perfect, who is considerate but clumsy, and may be invisible. Like Nick, A Simple Machine, Like the Lever is short, toned, observant, generous, purposeful, and brimming with bicycle wisdom. Card cover, 184 pages Free UK delivery Tweet

name: Condor: Past Present Future Book SOLD OUT
description: Condor: Past Present Future A collaborative book between Condor Cycles and the guys behind The Ride Journal The book is an extensive guide to the very finest bicycles from one of the oldest British cycling firms. The book discusses the evolution of frames and material and how they strive to still make bicycles by hand. Condor is dedicated to the passion of cycling and the art of design and it’s a mix that has attracted Mick Jagger, Jon Snow and Eric Clapton to the brand, with Clapton choosing to design a frame for Condor. Amongst the history are photo stories from their factory, the London build centre and short essays from customers about their time on the bike. It is book that celebrates 65 years of bicycle design by Condor and the things that are still to come. Embossed Card Cover 150 pages Size: 240mm x 170mm Price includes UK delivery Tweet

name: The Boneshaker Almanac Volume 7
description: The Boneshaker Almanac Volume 7 (BA43-200) Modeled loosely after the United States War Department’s 1941 Soldier’s Basic Field Manual, Boneshaker: A Bicycling Almanac fashions itself to be the practical bicyclist’s literary periodical-style handbook. The almanac is a collective ode to the ride itself, that fundamentally lonesome experience one has in the saddle, and the results of repeating that ride over and over in different directions on different days with different destinations in each instance. With interviews of respected members of the bicycling community, as well as profiles of bike-related grassroots organizations and individuals, not to mention essays, graphs, lists, letters, charts, maps, poems, schedules, manifestos, drawings, art, and stories, the Boneshaker Almanac attempts to shine light on utilitarian bicycling. In the latest installment you will be reunited with Smidge & Space who are riding their bicycles as far west as they can go in Maureen Foley’s excellent graphic memoir excerpt. You will find superb and inspiring profiles of several families across the U.S. who are using bicycles as their primary mode of transportation. You will also not want to miss London-based writer and photographer Julian Birch explaining the pitfalls of the phenomenon known as Bicycle Retail Therapy. To boot, Jonny Waldman’s enlightening travelogue will have you doubled over laughing, while Marc-Andre Chimonas’ interview with Renold Yip of Fort Collins’ own Yipsan Bicycles will have you yearning for an artisan frame this fall. Complete will poetry, a film-by-film review of the 10th annual Bicycle Film Festival, another full moon ride schedule, and a handy chart for riding in pairs, issue BA 43-200 will make excellent reading as you break from riding through all those fallen leaves. We are the only stockist outside of the United States of this publication 128 pages, perfect bound Free UK delivery Tweet

name: To Live & Ride in L.A. DVD SOLD OUT
description:
To Live and Ride in L.A. DVD Directed by David Rowe For fixed-gear cyclists, Los Angeles is a city that has it all. From the neon glow of Hollywood to the sun-drenched boardwalk of Venice Beach, fixed-gear has evolved into a vibrant street culture that is uniquely L.A. From director David Rowe (Fast Friday) comes a new documentary feature that explores a side of L.A. few outsiders have seen. From races through rush-hour traffic to midnight loft parties, To Live & Ride in L.A. is a fast paced-trip through the busy streets and back-alleys of one of the world's largest cities. To Live & Ride In L.A. features talented local riders tearing up the streets with first-time visitor Keo Curry (Fast Friday & Macaframa). Bike to hidden spots off the map, race a midnight alley-cat, keep pace with the riders from Wolfpack, and hang with the local crews, graffiti artists and other L.A. personalities. The DVD has 40 minutes of exclusive extras including Behind the Scenes Footage, Lord of Griffith Race Featurette, Deleted Scenes, Freestyle Trick Sequences, Official Trailers & Teasers and Featured Riders Bonus Footage. All orders for To Live & Ride in L.A. come with a To Live & Ride in LA spokecard, a TRAFIK 6.5'' die cut Vinyl decal (produced for the riders in the film)

name: Asphalt Warrior Book - Kurt Boone (Signed)
description: Asphalt Warrior by Kurt Boone The Story of New York City's Fastest Messenger In New York City's business districts, billion of dollars are traded everyday and power deals are closed every minute. Within the hundreds of skyscrapers there are dedicated messenger centers that insure and time to the minute the delivery of business documents used to complete deals large and small. Kurt Boone has worked as a foot messenger for over 14 years, rushing throughout the city in all weather conditions, picking up and delivering these critical business documents. In Asphalt Warrior he tells his story as one of the fastest messengers in the city and his experiences in the now world-famous messenger culture, describing the messenger lifestyle of parties, alleycat racing, riding fixed bicycles and carrying messenger bags to and from the most high-end office buildings and residential apartment buildings in the world. name: The Ride Journal Issue 5 SOLD OUT
description: The Ride Journal Issue 5 Continuing where the previous issues have left off they turn away from the race reports, route guides and bike reviews. Instead they’re still focusing on the riders themselves and the passion that pumps through their veins. Covering all aspects of cycling there is everything from Scottish track racing, French BMX, Alpine freeriding, Spring Classics road races, commuting in Kampala, Japanese framebuilders, Canadian mountain biking and even a postman lamenting the sad loss of the post-bike. As ever it’s not about the big names inside but we are very happy to have Graeme Obree, Michael Barry, Jamie Bestwick, David Millar and even djing legend Norman Jay joining us in this issue. As well as the eclectic selection of articles The Ride Journal have also got a whole host of illustrators and photographers who once again bring a new dimension to the pieces with their killer art, including one of Singletrack readers favourite photographers Dan Barham. 176 pages This is quite a weighty magazine, price includes UK postage

name: The Boneshaker Almanac Volume 6 SOLD OUT
description: The Boneshaker Almanac Volume 6 (BA43-100) Modeled loosely after the United States War Department’s 1941 Soldier’s Basic Field Manual, Boneshaker: A Bicycling Almanac fashions itself to be the practical bicyclist’s literary periodical-style handbook. The almanac is a collective ode to the ride itself, that fundamentally lonesome experience one has in the saddle, and the results of repeating that ride over and over in different directions on different days with different destinations in each instance. With interviews of respected members of the bicycling community, as well as profiles of bike-related grassroots organizations and individuals, not to mention essays, graphs, lists, letters, charts, maps, poems, schedules, manifestos, drawings, art, and stories, the Boneshaker Almanac attempts to shine light on utilitarian bicycling. BA 43-100 hits the newsstands packed with stories, interviews, poems, reviews, and more, all conveniently packaged in an ever-attractive pocket-sized volume sure to help you ride out the winter blues. With a segment from a bike-themed graphic novel, a hand-drawn map to Nirvana, a story on nationwide potlucking, the truth about kickback coaster brake hubs, a couple of publication pen pals, a ride on a Swedish army bike, and a guide to the best days to ride this year. We are the only stockist outside of the United States of this publication 128 pages, perfect bound Free UK delivery Tweet

name: Klunkerz DVD: A Film about the Birth of Mountain Bikes SOLD OUT
description: Klunkerz A Film about the Birth of Mountain Bikes Long before the mountain bike entered our global consciousness, the cycling enthusiasts of Northern California's Marin County rode modified pre-WWII bicycles down the slopes of Mount Tamalpais. They developed their bikes through rigorous field-testing, often risking life and limb to do so. It was from these humble beginnings that a multi-billion dollar industry, a form of recreation for the masses, and an Olympic event, were born. These hefty steeds were affectionately known as Klunkerz. Klunkerz is a fast-moving documentary that traces the global rise of mountain biking from it's Marin County roots, a gonzo sport long favored by fearless iconoclasts. An outgrowth of the Bay Area's late-'60s early-'70s hippy counterculture, mountain biking got its start right in MVFF's backyard. Pot-smoking adrenaline junkies from Mill Valley, Larkspur and surrounding towns took their pre-World War II bicycles known as klunkerz due to their fat tires, to the top of Mt. Tamalpais, then hurled themselves down dirt paths, risking life and limb in search of a killer high. Archival footage, rare photos and interviews with klunkerz trailblazers merge in this terrific film that races downhill toward mountain-bike bliss. Starring: Joe Breeze, Gary Fisher, Alan Bonds, Charlie Kelly, Tom Ritchey, Russ Mahon, Bob Burrowes, Wende Cragg, Charlie Cunningham, Otis Guy, Jaquie Phelan, Steve Potts, John Finley Scott, Robert Stewart, Fred Wolf. Directed & Prodcued by Billy Savage, Director of Photography: Glenn Evans. Associate Producer & Composer: Tommy Coster, Jr. Editor/Co-Writer: Jeffrey Abelson

name: Ride the Divide DVD
description: Ride the Divide An award-winning feature film about the world's toughest mountain bike race, which traverses over 2700 miles along the Continental Divide in the Rocky Mountains. The film weaves the story of three characters' experiences with immense mountain beauty and small-town culture as they attempt to pedal from Banff, Canada to a small, dusty crossing on the Mexican border. Ride The Divide is an inspiring journey about the world’s toughest mountain bike race, which traverses over 2700 miles along the Continental Divide in the Rocky Mountains. The film weaves the story of three characters’ experiences with immense mountain beauty and small-town culture as they attempt to pedal from Banff, Canada to a small, dusty crossing on the Mexican border. Mike, a 40-year old family man who uses this challenge to chart a new course in life; Matthew, a leader in extreme endurance racing who’s competing for his 5th time; and Mary, the ﬁrst female rider to race this route, will set out to accomplish what very few have been able to. Over the course of a few weeks they’ll attempt to climb over 200,000 vertical feet over the Rocky Mountains. That’s the equivalent of ascending Mount Everest from sea level seven times. They’ll experience mental breakdowns, treacherous snow, hellacious blisters, and total fatigue. Above all, they’ll race with no support – at times in total isolation. Extras: Matthew Lee's Divide Racing Bike, Extended Interviews, Deleted Scenes, Racers' Daily Audio Call In's, Filmmaker Audio Commentary. Free UK Shipping Tweet

name: Bespoke: The Handbuilt Bicycle
description: Bespoke: The Handbuilt Bicycle The publication presents the designs of six internationally renowned bicycle builders whose embrace of the tradition of working in metal brings striking innovation to their craft. Through their manipulation of steel, aluminum and titanium, the builders of Bespoke produce racing bicycles that speed champion athletes to victory, mountain and cyclocross bicycles built to negotiate vertiginous terrain, urban bicycles that stylishly convey commuters, and randonneur bicycles elegantly stripped down for epic journeys. Candid portraits including builder’s inspirations, working methods and bicycles, lavishly photographed in great detail, highlight this exhibition at New York’s Museum of Arts and Design. Bespoke offers a rich and intimate view of objects that sit squarely at the intersection of art, design, craft and performance. With contributions by Michael Maharam and Sacha White (Vanilla Bicycles). Photographs by D. James Dee. Includes bicycles by the following builders: Mike Flanigan (A.N.T), Jeff Jones, Dario Pegoretti, Richard Sachs, J. Peter Weigle and Sacha White (Vanilla Bicycles) 128 pages with approx. 150 illustrations Tweet

name: Velo: Bicycle Culture and Design
description: Velo: Bicycle Culture and Design edited by R. Klanten and S. Ehmann Velo is a striking visual journey into the multifaceted world of cycling and the diverse tribes that inhabit it. These range from hardcore 2-wheel globetrotters, downtown messengers on fixed-gear bikes without brakes, laid back pedallers on old-fashioned Dutch bicycles, fashionable cyclists on vintage racing bikes, and dedicated fans of high-tech racing machines and e-bikes. The book also gives insider views into the production halls of renowned Italian and French brands as well as the workshops of a new generation of passionate frame builders in the US. Velo presents the design and visual aesthetic of today’s cycling culture. The book features examples of T-shirts, caps, bags, flyers, and special equipment such as the spoke cards that bike messengers use in their alleycat races. It also explores the impact the cycling movement is making on contemporary art. In addition, Velo documents the relevance of bicycles in both rural and urban areas. It introduces innovative urban planning concepts such as the new bike lanes that are currently emerging in Manhattan and Copenhagen. 240 pages, full colour, soft cover Free UK mainland shipping Tweet

name: Bike Snob: Systematically & Mercilessly Realigning the World of Cycling
description: Bike Snob: Systematically & Mercilessly Realigning the World of Cycling Book by Eben Weiss Cycling is exploding in a good way. Urbanites everywhere, from ironic hipsters to earth-conscious commuters, are taking to the bike like aquatic mammals to water. BikeSnobNYC cycling's most prolific, well-known, hilarious, and anonymous blogger brings a fresh and humorous perspective to the most important vehicle to hit personal transportation since the horse. Bike Snob treats readers to a laugh-out-loud rant and rave about the world of bikes and their riders, and offers a unique look at the ins and outs of cycling, from its history and hallmarks to its wide range of bizarre practitioners. Throughout, the author lampoons the missteps, pretensions, and absurdities of bike culture while maintaining a contagious enthusiasm for cycling itself. Bike Snob is an essential volume for anyone who knows, is, or wants to become a cyclist. 5 x 7 in 208 pp with 2-colour line drawings throughout 16 page full-colour photo insert 4 Bike Snob NYC stickers Hardcover Free UK Shipping Tweet

name: The Revival Fixed Gear DVD
description: The Revival DVD The Revival brings together 17 of the worlds best fixed gear riders to show the many different styles of riding that exist within the sport. In 2009 the sport felt very undefined with branches of the sport shooting off in all directions. They wanted to capture all of this whether it was the bmx-influenced tricks on the East coast or the more traditional track bike tech tricks from the West. They also wanted to show that speed is still a defining side of the sport and they captured some of the fastest riders on the planet rocketing down the mountain sides of Vancouver BC. The Revival was an attempt that successfully helps define the sport and its entire make up while breathing some new life into the community. The most progressive fixed gear riding ever documented from both coasts of North America. Riders from Seattle, Vancouver, Toronto and New York City have unearthed the potential of these modern day machines. Hill bombs in excess of 80 km/h and tricks that have never been captured before on film tell the story of what this movement is all about. This ain’t your grandad’s bicycle anymore, this is The Revival. Free UK Shipping

name: Refresh BMX DVD 2 Disc Set
description: Refresh DVD Refresh took a year and a half from conception to completion. This video depicts the BMX lifestyle. It is the culmination of all the trips and sessions, all of the triumphs and failures. BMX is, and always will be, about having fun and hanging out with your buddies. It is more than a hobby, and its something that will always be there for us. The places we see and the people we meet along the way become life long friends and it’s all because of a bicycle. Refresh brings you the local street riders of Seattle and Bellingham. Filmed in HD by Brian Chace, who also brought you Here and Now, and Fresh Fish. The video starts off with a bang with Def Paul and goes into Chris Martindale, Scott Fuller, Shay Schiefelbein, Michael Chace, Greg Tylosky and closes with Joseph Pennell. Every part is solid and every rider has their own unique style. Refresh is a double disc set with the main feature on disc #1 and all of the Refresh Web Edits on Disc #2. name: Pedal - Bike Messenger Book & DVD Set
description: Pedal Photographs & a Documentary Film by Peter Sutherland. Texts by Zephyr, Ken Miller & Swoon A Book & DVD Set Best-selling author Peter Sutherland's newest title, Pedal, is a wild ride alongside a band of New York City's most feared and respected inhabitants: bike messengers. In a book of photographs and a documentary on DVD, Sutherland follows the frenetic trips and lives of the cyclists who live by their own rules of the road. In Pedal, Sutherland documents bike messengers competing in the 2005 Cycle Messenger World Championships in New York City. Going straight to the center of this urban subculture, Sutherland serves up compelling portraits of the competitors from dozens of countries, in motion and at ease, checking out each other's bags, lingering over modifications to bikes and bodies. Between events like sprints, distance racing, and skid contests, Sutherland shows us the riders' elegant physicality, complex individuality, and unique community that crosses boundaries of race, gender, age, and class. And he doesn't shy away from the blood and bruises that come part and parcel with the messenger's life. Sutherland delves deep into the world of the messengers--a world usually seen from the outside--and returns with a dynamic document that evokes the unbridled anarchy and energy of its inhabitants. The accompanying DVD is a fast-paced documentary film about surviving in the streets of New York City as a bicycle messenger. It features messengers from all walks of life as they battle traffic in a race to make their next delivery on time. Directed by Sutherland and produced by Ana Lombardo, Pedal the documentary lets viewers live the spectacle of the delivery itself. 112 Pages 97 full colour photographs DVD approx 56 minutes.

name: The Golden Age of Handbuilt Bicycles
description: The Golden Age of Handbuilt Bicycles Craftmanship, Elegance and Function Jan Heine, Jean Pierre Praderes During the "Golden Age," small makers built amazing bicycles that transcended their function to become a form of art. Their craftsmanship was not limited to the frame, but included hand-made derailleurs, brakes, stems, racks and other components. The entire bicycle was carefully designed and crafted as a unit, combining function and beauty. Famous makers like René Herse, Alex Singer, Jo Routens and others spent countless hours on each bicycle in their search for perfection. With lavish photography, The Golden Age of Handbuilt Bicycles charts the development of these machines from the early 1900s through the present day. The 50 classic bicycles in this book display amazing craftsmanship, elegance and function. Each brought innovations that continue to be used today. Additional historic photos show the bikes in competition and with their original owners. Insightful descriptions set the scene for each bicycle and explain its details. Here you find machines with a level of craftsmanship that never has been surpassed. Hardback 168 pages 200 Black & White illustrations Free delivery to the UK mainland
